Legal US Sports Betting Revenue, Handle And Tax Totals Since PASPA Repeal

Share on FacebookShare on Twitter
byChris Altruda
July 7, 2025

With around $13 billion in Sports Betting Revenue, $150 billion in Sports Betting Handle, and nearly $3 billion in taxes – all in 2024 alone – sports betting in the US continued its growth. For 2025, not all states have reported yet, but the available data for the first five months shows more than $65 billion wagered, generating almost $6 billion in revenue and over $1 billion in taxes.

This steady growth is a direct result of the major regulatory shift that began in 2018.

The U.S. gambling industry, including casinos, lotteries, and daily fantasy sports sites, scored a monumental win in May 2018 when the U.S. Supreme Court overturned the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act of 1992. That opened the floodgates to state-by-state legalization and regulation of sports betting.

Previously, single-game sports wagering was confined to the state of Nevada, and Las Vegas became the mecca of U.S. sports betting. However, legal sports wagering has expanded to 38 states and DC and counting as of 2024 and is showing no signs of slowing down anytime soon. The American Gaming Association previously estimated that sports bettors in the U.S. were wagering $150 billion annually, prior to the overturning of PASPA, yet only about $5 billion of that was happening legally — in Nevada.

Some states have legalized only brick and mortar (B&M) sportsbooks for now, while others have also permitted online/mobile wagering; demand has been enormous and some states have seen as much as 90% of all bets in the state placed via online/mobile.

Below is a look at reported figures by betting sites in the still-expanding U.S. market, now almost seven years since PASPA fell. Keep in mind some states report robust information regarding legal wagers, while in others, data is sparse.

Monthly U.S. Totals: Handle, Revenue, Hold, and Taxes

The following table shows the sports betting handle (total dollars wagered), sportsbook revenue (gross revenue produced by legal sportsbooks, collectively, and adjusted when applicable), hold percentage across all sportsbooks in the state (percentage of dollars wagered the sportsbooks “kept,” producing the revenue), and state taxes collected.

There are now two ways this data is tabulated. The first, immediately below, is on a month-by-month basis dating back to May 2018, the month that the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the 1992 federal ban on full-fledged sports wagering outside Nevada. The month-by-month totals also include calendar-year summaries following the December monthly totals.

Arizona Sports Betting Totals

Arizona completed a rather speedy process from governor’s signature to approval with its launch before the start of the NFL season in September 2021. Governor Doug Ducey and the state legislature were able to craft a bill that included tribal gaming interests as well as professional teams as both were able to obtain mobile and retail sports wagering licenses.

The Arizona Department of Gaming has issued 18 of the state’s 20 potential licenses, and there are currently more than 15 different operators accepting wagers online in the state. The first six months showed there was a sizable appetite for sports betting as handle totaled nearly $2.8 billion.

Arkansas Sports Betting Totals

Arkansas sports betting was made possible by voters, who approved Issue 4 in the 2018 November elections by a margin of 54.1-45.9 percent. Issue 4 provided the initiative to authorize casinos in five counties in the state that included three existing venues and two that will be built.

Oaklawn Racing Casino was the first to accept wagers in July 2019, and Saraceno Casino Resort followed suit two months later. Southland Casino Resort was the third to start taking wagers in January 2020, and the two remaining casinos are slated for Pope and Jefferson counties.

Arkansas approved mobile wagering to ring in 2022 with a controversial revenue-sharing model that has not been looked at kindly by operators. Betly Sportsbook was the first online platform to launch in the state, going live in April 2022, and has since been joined by Bet Saracen and Oaklawn Sports.

Colorado Sports Betting Totals

Colorado sports betting was made possible by ballot referendum in November 2019, when the measure to legalize narrowly passed by 1%. The industry and player-friendly regulations to follow have resulted in what’s basically a robust test market for all groups looking to gain a foothold in the U.S. market — including Las Vegas-based Circa Sportsbook.

There may be up to 33 online sportsbooks available, one for each casino, and one physical lounge at each property. The first NFL team/sportsbook partnership was also struck in Colorado, when the Denver Broncos and FanDuel Sportsbook hooked up in June 2020.

Connecticut Sports Betting Totals

The Nutmeg State legalized sports wagering on May 19, 2021, by Gov. Ned Lamont and launched six months later on Oct. 19, but getting to that point was sometimes a painstaking process. Connecticut has a semi-hybrid approach in which the two key gaming venues in the state run by the tribes — Foxwoods (Mashentucket Pequot) and Mohegan — have teamed with DraftKings and FanDuel, respectively, with those compacts for Class III Gaming published in September. The Connecticut Lottery is now partnered with Fanatics Sportsbook after its original partnership with SugarHouse was terminated.

  • Number of brick-and-mortar sportsbooks operating: 4
  • Number of retail sites: 16 (XL Center opened in Sep. 2023)
  • Number of online sportsbooks operating: 3
  • Leading sportsbooks: DraftKings operates via Foxwoods, FanDuel operates via Mohegan Sun, and Fanatics Sportsbook operates via the Connecticut Lottery.
  • Tax rate on sportsbook operators: The tax rate is 13.75% on adjusted gaming revenue, with operators permitted to set aside 15% of gross revenue as promotional. The percentage, which was introduced at 25% when legalized, gets reduced by five percentage points every 12 months until it zeroes out.

Delaware Sports Betting Totals

The First State was actually among four states (including Nevada, Oregon, and Montana that had limited sports wagering “grandfathered” under PASPA, allowing the Delaware Lottery to offer NFL parlay betting even after Congress passed the ban. Once PASPA was struck down, Delaware beat New Jersey to the punch, accepting the first straight bet outside Nevada on June 5, 2018. Online sportsbook apps became legal in January 2024 when the Delaware Lottery allowed BetRivers to offer digital sports wagering in addition to online casino gaming.

  • Leading sportsbooks: For all three sportsbooks in the state, Scientific Games operates systems and software, while Caesars Sportsbook (formerly William Hill) manages oddsmaking/risk-management.
  • Tax rate on sportsbook operators: Delaware uses a revenue-sharing arrangement that gives 12.5% to Scientific Games, and the remaining amount is divided between the state (50%) and casinos that take the wagers (40%). The remaining 10% is taken out to support the state’s horse tracks.

District of Columbia Sports Betting Totals

It took a while for the nation’s capital to get going after the D.C. Council legalized it in December 2018 and Mayor Muriel Bowser signed the measure into law in January 2019. The first bets through the city’s mobile app, GambetDC, run by DC Lottery, were not made until May 2020.

The road to launch had a series bumps and hiccups, and many people ultimately were not thrilled with the GambetDC platform and offerings. Bookmaker William Hill entered the field in August 2020, with a physical sportsbook at Capital One Arena — the first sportsbook to operate at a sporting venue in the United States. BetMGM recently followed suit with a retail location at Nationals Park, which officially opened its doors on January 31, 2022.

The access to mobile sports betting greatly expanded in the summer of 2024 after the D.C. Council passed a Fiscal Year 2025 budget that included both overhauling and increasing the tax rates as more operators began conducting wagering.

Illinois Sports Betting Totals

The first brick-and-mortar sportsbook in Illinois launched on March 9, 2020 at the Rivers Casino in Des Plaines, followed by the Argosy Casino Alton three days later. The Illinois enabling legislation for sports betting originally required in-person registration for online betting accounts, which expired March 5, 2022.

Mobile wagering took off in Illinois thanks to Gov. JB Pritzker’s Executive Order suspending the in-person provision, which he extended on multiple occasions throughout the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and into 2021. BetRivers Sportsbook was the first sportsbook to go live online in the Land of Lincoln (through Rivers Casino), and there are currently nine total mobile operators accepting action in the state following Hard Rock Bet’s entrance in late August 2024.

Illinois became the fourth state to post a $1 billion monthly handle in October 2022 and the third to clear $100 million in operator venue in the same month. It also became the first state to have a solely progressive tax for sports wagering when it was passed in May 2024 as part of Pritzker’s Fiscal Year 2025 budget. The new tax rates, which begin at 20% and could reach as high as 40% for operators based on revenue, took effect July 1, 2024.

Indiana Sports Betting Totals

The first brick-and-mortar sportsbooks in Indiana launched shortly before the 2019 football season and online sportsbooks followed shortly thereafter. Betting handle has steadily increased each month following the resumption of sports post-COVID-19, and alongside it, as more sportsbooks came online, the percentage of legal wagers placed via mobile devices/online increased to roughly 90%. The Hoosier State is an open, competitive marketplace that has long flourished even with bordering states Ohio and Kentucky also legalizing.

Iowa Sports Betting Totals

Iowa was one of fastest fastest-moving states from legalization to launch, needing only three months. State sportsbooks launched retail and mobile on the same day. With the turning of the calendar to 2021, bettors in Iowa had remote registration available to open a mobile sports wagering account as the in-person provision expired at the end of 2020. Since the COVID-19 pandemic has subsided, Iowa’s handle has grown steadily. The Hawkeye State topped $250 million for the first time in October 2021.

Kansas Sports Betting Totals

The Sunflower State blazed one of the fastest trails in the nation from governor’s signature to taking wagers, with Gov. Laura Kelly signing SB 84 into law on May 12, the law taking effect July 1, and Kansas opening for sports betting business Sep. 1. There will be a maximum of 12 mobile operators in Kansas, with each retail venue allowed three online skins.

Six operators were on the starting line Sept. 1, with Kansas Crossing Casino already maxing out its allotment of skins. Boot Hill Casino, Kansas Star Casino, and Hollywood Casino Kansas all currently have one mobile skin to offer Kansas residents and the opportunity to offer more for interested operators. The Sunflower State came out of the gate fast with an initial handle of $160 million as operators aggressively sought an early foothold in the Midwestern state via promotional play.

Kentucky Sports Betting Totals

The Bluegrass State is no longer just for betting on horse racing. Democrat and former Kentucky Attorney General Andy Beshear made legalizing sports betting one of his campaign planks when he ran for governor of the commonwealth in 2019, and signed it into law at the end of March 2023. House Bill 551 was quickly passed in Kentucky state legislature prior to getting Beshear’s signature.

Each of the state’s nine horse racing tracks has the ability to align with three mobile operators, creating the potential for as many as 27 online options. Kentucky launched retail wagering at those tracks Sept. 7, with seven mobile sportsbooks at the ready to begin taking bets three weeks later. Kentucky fans will be able to wager on their beloved Wildcats during college basketball season as there are no carveouts regarding in-state schools.

Kentucky also has the unique distinction of some sportsbooks allowing bettors as young as 18 to place wagers compared to the traditional age of 21.

Louisiana Sports Betting Totals

Louisiana was able to launch retail sports betting within one calendar year after voters approved it on a parish-by-parish basis in a November 2020 referendum. Overall, 55 of the state’s 64 parishes approved sports wagering, and thanks to geofencing technology, mobile wagering will be conducted where approved. Hurricane Ida, however, slowed the path for launching mobile wagering as the Louisiana State Patrol is in charge of the vetting process for operator applications.

The Pelican State finally managed to roll out mobile sports betting on January 28, 2022, with nationwide leaders such as FanDuel, DraftKings, Caesars, and BetMGM getting the party started. The state is now home to nine different mobile sportsbooks and has carved out a strong digital gambling community since launch.

Each of the state’s 20 casinos/racinos can operate up to two mobile sportsbook brands apiece under their licenses, opening the possibility for up to 40 brands to eventually launch in Louisiana!

Maine Sports Betting Totals

Sports wagering reached the furthest point geographically in the northeastern part of the United States in November 2023 when it became the fifth U.S. jurisdiction to go live in the calendar year. It did take some time to get to that point — the state took up sports betting as a potential option as early as 2019, but it wasn’t until state law LD 585 passed in April 2022 and signed into law by Gov. Janet Mills one month later that it was legalized.

The bill granted sports wagering licenses to Maine’s four federally recognized Indian tribes, giving them the option to pair up with one operator. The state’s two casinos and six off-track betting locations can also offer sports betting, but that will only be conducted in-person at those venues.

Maryland Sports Betting Totals

Maryland voters legalized sports betting via referendum on a simple “yes” or “no” question in November 2020, and Gov. Larry Hogan signed a sports betting measure into law in May 2021. While there have been fits and starts moving forward, retail sports wagering did launch before the end of the calendar year in early December 2021.

That was the lone source of wagering for much of 2022 as the regulatory progress for mobile wagering progressed at a much slower rate than retail. There is plenty of appetite for wagering as the law allows for up to 60 sportsbook licenses in Maryland, with a focus on “lens of inclusion” offering opportunities for women-owned and minority-owned sportsbooks to enter the marketplace.

There are 13 entities that will be able to offer a mobile sports betting skin with their licenses, including the Baltimore Ravens, Baltimore Orioles, and Washington Commanders, and there was incentive to get them up and running quickly considering the Old Line State is surrounded by states and jurisdictions already offering sports betting in Virginia, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and West Virginia.

Massachusetts Sports Betting Totals

Sports betting finally launched in the Bay State on Jan. 31 at Encore Boston Harbor, MGM Springfield, and Plainridge Park, bringing a happy ending to a multi-year process of fits and starts and near-stalls in state legislature. Mobile betting was not far behind, with six mobile platforms accepting their first bets March 10 — during the hight of college basketball conference tournament play and six days before the state of the real March Madness — the NCAA Tournament.

The tax rates are 15% for retail sportsbook revenue and 20% for online operator revenue. There is a carveout for college wagering that prohibits placing bets on regular-season games involvng in-state schools, which eliminates wagering on the likes of Boston College, Harvard, UMass, Northeastern, and Boston University, BUT bettors can place wagers on them for tournament games, including the NCAA Tournament.

Michigan Sports Betting Totals

Sports betting is now legal in the great state of Michigan. After a surprising veto by outgoing Governor Rick Snyder in December 2018 of a bill that had bipartisan support, lawmakers were able to seal the deal with Snyder’s successor Gretchen Whitmer in December 2019.

Sports betting is allowed at all three of Detroit’s commercial casinos, and legislators were able to work in tandem with tribes across the Great Lakes State as well. In total, 20 of the state’s 26 casinos now offer retail sports betting in some form. A little less than one year after its retail sports betting debut, the Wolverine State launched online sports wagering en masse on January 22, 2021.

Mississippi Sports Betting Totals

Mississippi was one of a handful of states able to offer legal sports betting without passing new legislation, having preemptively legalized in 2019, contingent upon federal law changing (which it did). The state’s gaming commission oversees commercial casinos, and there are also a handful of tribal venues. Despite attempts to consider expanding betting beyond casino properties via mobile wagering, Mississippi remains the largest retail-driven state for sports betting.

Montana Sport Betting Totals

Run by the Montana Lottery, sports betting has been in available since March 2020. Sports wagering was made legal in March 2019 with the passage of House Bill 725 — the Sports Wagering Lottery Amendment Act of 2019 — which established the state lottery as the sole operator for sports betting.

Though sports betting can be done via smartphone, bettors must be on-site at a lottery location in order to place wagers through Sports Bet Montana. People, though, can use the app to set up their accounts — which includes depositing and withdrawing funds, setting bet limits and preparing bet slips. The Montana Lottery sports betting platform is powered by Intralot.

Nebraska Sport Betting Totals

It was an arduous path to bring legal sports wagering to Nebraska after voters approved a referendum for casinos to expand their offerings to include sports betting. While the process of legalizing via law was a relatively short affair — Gov. Pete Ricketts signed LB 561 into law in May 2021 — the crafting of rules and regulations for a state lacking a mobile option proved slow and occasionally frustrating.

It is a two-pronged challenge to generate notable handle in Nebraska between the lack of mobile wagering and the carveout preventing wagers on in-state colleges and universities. Given the universal appeal of Nebraska football and also the recent rise of Creighton basketball, retail sportsbooks will have to appeal to fans of pro teams for the bulk of their wagering.

Nevada Sports Betting Totals

Nevada has had legal sports betting since 1949, but lags behind more recent entries by requiring in-person registration for mobile accounts. Blame this on hospitality — many large resorts house sportsbooks and want to see patrons walk through the door and spend money on food or other gaming while registering for an account.

New Jersey passed Nevada in handle in May 2019, less than one year after New Jersey sportsbooks took their first bets. In the two-plus years mobile handle statistics have been available, mobile wagering has accounted for nearly two-thirds of overall handle in that span.

New Hampshire Sports Betting Totals

New Hampshire legalized sports betting and appeared headed toward offering an open, competitive marketplace, as the enabling legislation permits up to 10 unique online sportsbooks. However, after the request-for-proposal phase, the New Hampshire Lottery opted to give DraftKings Sportsbook a monopoly on both retail and mobile sports betting.

DraftKings offered the state a sweet deal on tax revenue to get the monopoly, but bettors now only have a single option. DraftKings launched its mobile app in late December 2019, and handle finally topped $100 million in March 2023 after flirting with it on a few occasions. The state collects a hefty 51% of gross gaming revenue as part of a deal for DraftKings to be the only operator in the state.

New Jersey Sports Betting Totals

Every other “legal” state owes a debt of gratitude to New Jersey, which led the fight against PASPA and finally claimed victory in 2018. Very quickly after the Supreme Court ruling, New Jersey passed its new law formally legalizing sports betting and establishing rules and regulations. New Jersey’s open, competitive market has proved a huge success and a model for other states.

After only four years, the Garden State established itself as a friendly rival to Nevada in both market size and sportsbook innovation and became the first state to post a $1 billion monthly handle and at least $100 million in monthly operator revenue. New Jersey sportsbook lounges are open at many Atlantic City casinos, while the most popular sportsbook is a FanDuel lounge at the Meadowlands Racetrack adjacent to MetLife Stadium, about eight miles from New York City.

  • Biggest monthly gross revenue to date: $170,758,334 (Jan. ’24)

  • Number of online sportsbooks operating: 18
  • Leading sportsbooks (revenue and/or handle): FanDuel Sportsbook, DraftKings Sportsbook
  • Fun fact: New Jersey was the first state to post a $1 billion monthly handle in the post-PASPA era in September 2021.
  • Tax rates on operators: 13% for online revenue, 8.5% for land-based revenue

New York Sports Betting Totals

It’s complicated. An economic/gaming law passed in 2013 preemptively approved land-based sportsbooks at upstate casinos. One of former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s final acts before his resignation was to get the framework in place for mobile wagering. While many blanched at the 51% tax rate, every operator knew it could not risk potentially missing out on the vast New York market and applied.

The result? Nine operators were approved as part of two super bids in which rivals became allies of convenience. The New York State Gaming Commission moved in rapid-fire fashion through the fall to launch during the first full weekend of 2022 with four operators — BetRivers, Caesars, DraftKings, and FanDuel — able to accept wagers. BetMGM, PointsBet, WynnBET, and Resorts World Bet followed suit, and Bally Bet completed the field.

PointsBet gave way to Fanatics Sportsbook in early 2024, while WynnBET departed at the end of July. WynnBET sold its license to PENN Entertainment, which brought ESPN BET to the Empire State in late September.

  • Legalization date: Sportsbook lounges at upstate casinos were preemptively legalized in 2013; rules and regulations were created post-PASPA
  • New York legal retail sportsbooks first launched: July 16, 2019
  • New York legal mobile sportsbooks first launched: Jan. 8, 2022
  • Regulator: New York State Gaming Commission
  • The biggest monthly handle to date: $2,487,676,802 (Jan. ’25).
  • Biggest monthly gross revenue to date: $248,001,821 (Jan. ’25)
  • Number of brick-and-mortar sportsbooks operating: 11
  • Number of online sportsbooks operating: 9
  • Fun Facts:
    • In its first month of mobile wagering in January 2022, New York attained the “triple crown” of having the highest national monthly handle, gross gaming revenue, and state tax receipts in the post-PASPA era.
    • It is the only state to surpass $2 billion in monthly handle.
    • It is the only state to surpass $1 billion in tax revenue, doing so in May 2023.
  • Tax rate on sportsbook operators: 10% on land-based revenue; 51% on gross mobile revenue

North Carolina Sports Betting Totals

North Carolina picked the perfect time to enter the sports betting marketplace — right at the start of college basketball’s conference tournament week in March. Operators used that as a springboard to attract bettors with plenty of promotional offers for the NCAA men’s and women’s Tournaments. Tar Heel State operators got an unexpected boost via Tobacco Road, where North Carolina State’s men’s and women’s teams both advanced to the Final Four.

On the men’s side, the Wolfpack eliminated eternal rival Duke in the regional final. North Carolina bettors did not lack for options at launch as eight operators entered the state, including all the most popular mobile sportsbooks. It was a rather quick process from signature to first wager in the Tar Heel State, which begin in June 2023 when Gov. Roy Cooper signed HB347 into law.

Ohio Sports Betting Totals

With much fanfare, the Buckeye State rang in 2023 with sportsbooks able to take wagers. A simultaneous launch similar to Michigan, but larger in scope took place on Jan. 1 when 15 mobile platforms sprang to life for Ohio bettors to utilize. A state with six top-tier professional teams — Cavaliers, Indians, Reds, Browns, Bengals, and FC Cincinnati — along with one of the biggest Division I college programs in the Ohio State University, Ohio was instantly going to muscle its way into the top tier of states when it came to sports wagering handle.

They did that with ease as the $1.1 billion wagered in January trailed only New York, but Buckeye bettors also set a dubious national record — since eclipsed by New York — as the house claimed a whopping $208.9 million in revenue in a historic opening month of wagering.

Promotional offers were aggressive in the first few months after launch with Ohio offering operators a business-friendly 10% tax rate — though no tax break for promotional credits for the first four years. Gov. Mike DeWine doubled the tax rate to 20% after just five months of wagering without altering the timeline for tax breaks on credits.

Oregon Sports Betting Totals

Oregonians can bet on professional sports online via DraftKings or in person at either the Chinook Winds Casino Resort or Spirit Mountain Casino. Oregon was one of four states that were grandfathered in under PASPA to have sports betting, and the Lottery initially took advantage by developing ScoreBoard, which was its first foray into an online business.

Looking for similar success it enjoys in New Hampshire, DraftKings now serves as the odds provider to the Oregon Lottery as of 2022. The tribe that owns the Chinook Winds Casino was allowed to reopen its compact with the state to add sports betting, but not all tribes are in the same situation. The Oregon Lottery has a revenue-sharing agreement with DraftKings in which it keeps 51% of revenue generated. Oregon became the 19th state to surpass $1 billion all-time handle in November 2022.

Pennsylvania Sports Betting Totals

Pennsylvania was an early mover in terms of making sports betting legal — it did so nearly seven months before PASPA was overturned, but the road to offering live sports betting was long. At this point, Pennsylvania is among the nation’s more robust markets and and offers consumers multiple options both online and in person.

While the Keystone State has one of the highest tax rates in the country at the state level at 34%, mobile operators are allowed to deduct promotional play against gross revenue, which allows them to aggressively court business.

Rhode Island Sports Betting Totals

Rhode Island was quick to legalize sports betting after PASPA fell, but there’s no competition in the market — the state Lottery is the regulator and has a monopoly. Sports betting is available in person at two casinos, and online through a lottery-run platform, Sportsbook RI, which is associated with both Bally’s Twin River and Bally’s Tiverton.

The deal for the casinos is that they pay the state 51% of gross gaming revenue, while the state provides more support and equipment than regulators do in other states. Essentially, the casinos and online books are Lottery outposts.

South Dakota Sports Betting Totals

South Dakota executed a quick turnaround to launch sports betting in September 2021 just before the start of the NFL season. Voters had approved sports wagering on a retail-only basis the previous November for casinos in Deadwood — the town made famous by the HBO series and lead character Al Swearengen.

Governor Kristi Noem signed SB 44 into law in March, creating a framework for sports wagering, and rules were approved in August before a slight tweaking the day before launch. Mobile wagering is allowed through an operator app, but only on the physical grounds of the casino.

Tennessee Sports Betting Totals

Tennessee was the first state to offer exclusively online sports wagering, later to be joined by both Virginia and Wyoming. Sports betting became law in May 2019 when Gov. Bill Lee opted not to sign the Sports Gaming Act after it had been approved by legislature. Rick Staples had pre-filed House Bill 1 in November 2018, and it successfully navigated both bodies of legislature in the Volunteer State.

Given its unprecedented status as an online-only market, the Tennessee Education Lottery Corporation took a deliberate pace in crafting its sports wagering rules and eventually gave way to the current state agency overseeing sports betting — the Sports Wagering Council.

In May 2023, state legislatures did away with the much-derided 10% minimum hold effective July 1, 2023, and opted to change the method of taxation — opting to make the levy a percentage of the handle as opposed to operator revenue. The Volunteer State went live with four operators on Nov. 1, 2020, with one of them — Tennessee Action 24/7 — a local outfit that operates exclusively inside Tennessee’s borders.

Vermont Sports Betting Totals

Vermont was the first new state to enter the commercial marketplace in 2024 after a relatively quick process from legislature to first wager last year. That came after a slow buildup dating back to 2016 in which daily fantasy sports was ruled illegal, a decision that was overturned two years later.

An initial bill was authored in 2019, but that failed to move in the House. A study committee formed a year later was the precursor to the framework for the bill that passed, and H.B. 127 received approval from the House and Senate on May 9. Vermont Gov. Phil Scott signed it into law June 15, and the state’s Department of Liquor and Lottery serves as the state’s regulator.

The Green Mountain State is the third to conduct wagering exclusively on-line, joining Tennessee and Wyoming. DraftKings, Fanatics Sportsbook, and FanDuel were all on the starting line together for the Jan. 11 launch, and there is capacity for up to three more licensees. The Department of Liquor and Lottery did make one change from its initial rules and regulations, joining Ohio and Maryland as states that banned player-specific prop bets involving college games.

Vermont also has one unique aspect to its sports betting: Taxation. As opposed to a set rate, operators bid on their monthly levy to the state, though it had to be a minimum of 20%.

Virginia sports betting totals

Virginia put together a fairly quick timeline in moving from legalized sports betting in March 2020 to accepting its first wagers in January 2021. It joined Tennessee (and later Wyoming) as the only states to conduct digital-only sports betting as four operators went live during the first month of the year.

The Old Dominion has since added three retail sportsbooks as part of its gambling landscape. In its initial revenue report, Virginia showed promise with upside as it generated nearly $59 million in handle in just 11 days — and delivered on that potential by clearing $3 billion in wagers in its first full year. More operators have since entered the market, creating robust competition for lovers in Virginia who also love betting.

West Virginia sports betting totals

West Virginia is another state that legalized in anticipation of the fall of PASPA, but it did so with lots of plot twists and intrigue. Gov. Jim Justice is a part-owner of The Greenbrier Resort, which hosts a PGA Tournament and now offers retail and digital sports betting.

Justice pushed for a payout (“integrity fee“) to the leagues to no avail. The state’s first digital sportsbook went live in December 2018, only to be shut down ahead of March Madness in 2019 due to a contract dispute. After the rocky start, eight mobile books are currently operating, including industry leaders FanDuel, DraftKings, and Caesars.

Wyoming Sports Betting Totals

Wyoming was the first state to legalize sports betting in 2021 when Gov. Mark Gordon signed HB 133 into law in early April. The Equality State was fairly quick to get to market, accepting its first wagers in September as DraftKings and BetMGM were the first sportsbooks to operate in-state.

A fully digital state, Wyoming also became the first state to allow bettors to fund their accounts via cryptocurrency, and operators are required to have a reserve account that is in a bank in the state or chartered by the state. Big Wyoming has a 10% tax rate on revenue and allows wagering on professional, college, and Olympic sports.
